awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Modular, Efficient, Homomorphic Cryptography
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern computer applications require not only to protect data using encryption, but also to perform computations on data in encrypted form, e.g., in a cloud computing setting where private data is stored and processed on a remote, untrusted server. Lattice cryptography is a fast-developing area of mathematical cryptography which has the potential to deliver new and better solutions to many complex security problems, and currently the only known technique allowing the construction of fully homomorphic encryption schemes: encryption mechanisms that allow to perform arbitrary computations on encrypted data. Lattice cryptography also offers post-quantum security, i.e., it is believed to resist the future threat posed by the development of quantum computers. The project's novelties are the introduction of a new framework for the design and analysis of homomorphic encryption functions, and its use to improve the understanding of this important cryptographic primitive, as well as to improve its efficiency. The project impacts are enabling better methods to securely share and use data (in encrypted form), and inform ongoing efforts to standardize post-quantum cryptography and homomorphic encryption.

This project investigates a general framework for the modular design of complex cryptographic primitives based on lattices, including fully homomorphic encryption (FHE). Starting from a basic (private key) encryption scheme satisfying certain weak linear homomorphic properties, a variety of known homomorphic encryption schemes, as well as some new ones, are described in a unified, modular way, compared, analyzed and combined. Within this framework, several important problems are investigated. Specific questions considered in this project are: the design of circular secure FHE schemes, the construction of more efficient FHE schemes making use of amortized bootstrapping techniques, the use of hybrid solutions combining together different FHE schemes as well as forms of secure multiparty computation based on secret sharing, and the construction of multi-use universally composable oblivious transfer based on lattices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE) is a technology that allows to perform arbitrary computations on encrypted data, without revealing the input data, intermediate computations, or final results. As such, it is an important tool
to enable a wide range of "privacy preserving" applications, e.g., sharing of encrypted patient data between hospitals to perform a joint medical study, while preserving the privacy of the invididual users.
The possibility of performing computations on encrypted data is also a problem of central theoretical interest in cryptography and theoretical computer science. While some fundamental steps in developing FHE solutions have already
been taken during the last 15 years, there are still some major challenges to be overcome, both from the theoretical (security) point of view, and practical efficiency to make the use of FHE feasible in real applications. This research tackled some of the fundamental problems in the area, analyzing the security of proposed FHE schemes, discovering new attacks, developing and analyzing
countermeasures, improving the efficiency of existing constructions, and building a toolset to simply the development and analysis of new applications.

An important outcome of our research is the discovery that certain "approximate" FHE scheme (that were previously believed to be secure,) are subject to devastating key recovery attacks. Approxinate FHE is a variant of homomorphic encryption that allows to perform approximate computations.  The advantage of using approximate computations is that they can often be much more efficient than computing exact results, and still they are perfectly acceptable in many concrete application settings. For example, in many data science applications, the input data being encrypted is already the result of some approximate measurement, and therefore it is natural to consider approximate results just as good as exact ones. Due to its efficiency advantages, approximate FHE is very attractive in practice. But our findings show that approximate
computations on encrypted data can lead to a total loss of security and privacy, leaking the secret (decryption) key, and allowing an adversary to fully  decrypt the input data sets. Our research also produced a way to counter the security problem, while retaining most of the efficiency advantages of approximate FHE, and has guided the secure implementation of approximate homomorphic encryption in open source software libraries (OpenFHE), and is currently helping to make informed decisions towards the standardization of this useful technology.

The research produced a number of additional, more technical outcomes,  including more efficient versions of several lattice-based cryptographic protocols (Oblivious Transfer, amortized FHE  bootstrapping, threshold decryption, high rate encryption), and developing general mathematical tools for the analysis of lattice-based cryptography,  a class of cryptographic functions that are believed
to offer protection against attacks mounted using powerful quantum computers.
